content: SAG-AFTRA begins an ongoing strike after the national board failed to reach an agreement with the Motion Picture Association.
The FDA announces that the birth control pill Norgestrel, also known as Opill, will be available without a prescription.
A state judge in Oklahoma dismisses a lawsuit by the last three known survivors of the Tulsa race massacre in 1921 for reparations.

Patrick Crusius, the man who killed 23 people at an El Paso Walmart in 2019 is sentenced to 90 consecutive life sentences, the second longest prison sentence in American history and trailing only Oklahoma City Bombing accomplice Terry Nichols.
Meta Platforms launches Threads as a direct competitor to Twitter.
A mass shooting takes place in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, killing five and injuring two. The suspect was arrested later that day.
A mass shooting takes place in Baltimore, Maryland, killing two and injuring twenty-eight.
Apple Inc. closes with a market capitalization above $3 trillion for the first time, becoming the only public company to do so as of yet.
The Skyline light rail formally opens in Honolulu, Hawaii.

The Supreme Court rules 6â€“3 in 303 Creative LLC v. Elenis that the First Amendment prohibits states from forcing website designers to create designs they disagree with. The decision is seen as a victory for religious conservatives and free speech advocates but a setback for LGBT+ rights.
